citations.narrative:
At the time of the attempted inspection, it was determined that the licensee moved and is housing her animals covered by
the Animal Welfare Act (AWA) at a location that has not been disclosed or inspected and approved by the USDA, Animal
Care, back in January 2024. Licenses are issued to specific persons, and are issued for specific activities, types and
numbers of animals, and approved sites. Failure to provide such notifications prevents Animal Care’s inspection to assess
animal care and welfare and AWA compliance.
A licensee shall notify Animal Care no fewer than 90 days before any change in the name, address, management,
substantial control or ownership of his business or operation, locations, activities, and number or type of animals
described in 2.1(b)(2). Any person who is subject to the AWA and who intends to exhibit any animal at any location other
than the person’s approved site must submit written itineraries in accordance with § 2.126. The licensee must provide
these notifications as required by this regulation for any future occurrences.
Correct by: 22 APRIL 2024

citations.desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.
citations.narrative:
A responsible adult was not available to accompany APHIS Officials during the inspection process at 12:33 PM on
4/17/24.
The inspector arrived at 12:33 PM on 4/17/24 to conduct an inspection. The inspector contacted the designated facility
representative by phone upon arrival and learned that the facility representative was at a distant off-site location and could
not be available until much later in the day.
An AWA compliance inspection could not be conducted because there was no other authorized facility representative
available to accompany the inspector. Unannounced inspections are used to evaluate compliance with the AWA
Regulations and Standards. This is the FIRST attempted inspection of the Licensee.
Failure to provide access to the facility, animals, and records for inspection is a serious violation of the AWA and
regulations. Failure to comply may result in enforcement action.
End Section

narrative:
2.1(b)(1) 
   
Requirements and application 
At the time of the attempted inspection, it was determined that the licensee moved and is housing her animals covered by 
the Animal Welfare Act (AWA) at a location that has not been disclosed or inspected and approved by the USDA, Animal 
Care, back in January 2024. Licenses are issued to specific persons, and are issued for specific activities, types and 
numbers of animals, and approved sites. Failure to provide such notifications prevents Animal Care’s inspection to assess 
animal care and welfare and AWA compliance. 
 
A licensee shall notify Animal Care no fewer than 90 days before any change in the name, address, management, 
substantial control or ownership of his business or operation, locations, activities, and number or type of animals 
described in 2.1(b)(2). Any person who is subject to the AWA and who intends to exhibit any animal at any location other 
than the person’s approved site must submit written itineraries in accordance with § 2.126. The licensee must provide 
these notifications as required by this regulation for any future occurrences. 
 
Correct by: 22 APRIL 2024 
2.126(b) 
   
Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries. 
A responsible adult was not available to accompany APHIS Officials during the inspection process at 12:33 PM on 
4/17/24. 
 
The inspector arrived at 12:33 PM on 4/17/24 to conduct an inspection. The inspector contacted the designated facility 
representative by phone upon arrival and learned that the facility representative was at a distant off-site location and could 
not be available until much later in the day. 
 
An AWA compliance inspection could not be conducted because there was no other authorized facility representative 
available to accompany the inspector. Unannounced inspections are used to evaluate compliance with the AWA 
Regulations and Standards. This is the FIRST attempted inspection of the Licensee.

Failure to provide access to the facility, animals, and records for inspection is a serious violation of the AWA and 
regulations. Failure to comply may result in enforcement action. 
 
 
End Section
